title: How to Make Turnip Fries

steps.headline: Combine cornmeal, flour, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Add 1 cup (150 g) of fine plain white cornmeal, 1 cup (125 g) of all-purpose flour, 2 teaspoons (12 g) of kosher salt, and ½ teaspoon (1 g) of black pepper to a large bowl. Whisk the ingredients together so they’re well blended. If you like, you can add other seasonings to the coating for the turnip fries. Garlic powder, cayenne pepper, and paprika are some options to consider.

steps.headline: Toss the turnips in the buttermilk.
steps.description: Pour 2 cups (473 ml) of whole buttermilk into a large bowl. Add ¾ pound (340 g) of peeled turnips that have been cut into ⅓-inch (8-mm) thick sticks to the milk and toss well so they’re completely coated. If you don’t have buttermilk, use 2 cups (473 ml) of regular milk with 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of lemon juice mixed into it.

steps.headline: Coat the turnips with the cornmeal mixture.
steps.description: After you’ve coated the turnip sticks in the buttermilk, place them in the cornmeal mixture. Toss them in the cornmeal until the turnip fries are completely coated, and place them on a plate or baking sheet lined with foil or parchment paper.

steps.headline: Pour the oil into a skillet and heat.
steps.description: Fill a large skillet with ¼-inch (6-mm) of canola oil, and place it on the stove over medium heat. Allow the oil to heat for 5 to 7 minutes. You can substitute peanut or vegetable oil for the canola if you prefer.

steps.headline: Fry the turnips in batches until golden brown.
steps.description: Once the oil is heated, add the turnip fries to the skillet in batches. Cook them until they are golden brown, which should take approximately 5 minutes. Turn the fries occasionally with a spatula as they’re frying to ensure that they cook evenly.

steps.headline: Drain the fries and top with chives before serving.
steps.description: Use a slotted spoon to lift the turnip fries out of the oil and place them on a plate lined with paper towel. Allow the fries to drain for 2 to 3 minutes on the paper towel before transferring them to a platter. Sprinkle 2 tablespoons (6 g) of fresh, chopped chives over them and serve. You can serve the turnip fries with ketchup or your favorite dipping sauce.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and line a baking sheet.
steps.description: To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries, set the temperature to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (220 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully heat. Next, line a large baking sheet with parchment paper. You can substitute foil for the parchment paper if you prefer.

steps.headline: Toss the turnips with the oil and spices.
steps.description: Place 1 pound (454 g) of turnips that have been peeled and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) thick sticks into a large bowl. Add 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil, ½ teaspoon (3 g) of salt, ¼ teaspoon (½ g) of black pepper, ¼ teaspoon (2 g) of paprika, ¼ teaspoon (¼ g) of garlic powder, and ¼ teaspoon (¼ g) of dried parsley, and mix well so the turnips are completely coated. You can substitute coconut oil for the olive if you prefer.

steps.headline: Place the turnip fries on the baking sheet.
steps.description: When the turnip fries are seasoned, transfer them to the lined baking sheet. Spread them out in a single layer so they will cook evenly.

steps.headline: Bake the turnip fries for half an hour.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet in the preheated oven. Allow the turnip fries to bake for 30 minutes. At the 15 minute mark, turn the fries over with a spatula so they cook evenly on both sides.

steps.headline: Increase the oven temperature and cook for another 5 minutes.
steps.description: After the turnip fries have cooked for half an hour, increase the oven’s temperature to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius). Let the fries cook for another 5 minutes or until they are crispy. Keep a close eye on the fries for the last 5 minutes to ensure that they don’t burn.

steps.headline: Serve the fries while they are still hot.
steps.description: When the turnip fries are finished baking, remove the baking sheet from the oven. Transfer the fries to a platter, and serve them while they are still warm. You can serve the baked turnip fries with ketchup, garlic aioli, or your favorite fry dipping sauce.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and pans.
steps.description: Set two baking sheets inside the oven. Turn the oven on and set the temperature to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius). Allow both the pans and the oven to fully preheat. To make cleanup easier, you may want to line the baking sheets with foil or parchment paper.

steps.headline: Toss the turnip sticks with olive oil.
steps.description: Place 4 turnips that have been peeled and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) sticks in a large bowl. Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of olive oil, and toss well so that the turnip fries are well coated. While olive oil provides the best flavor, you can substitute canola or vegetable oil if you prefer.

steps.headline: Add the parmesan cheese and garlic salt to the fries.
steps.description: When the fries are coated with the oil, mix in 2 tablespoons (10 g) of grated Parmesan cheese and ¼ teaspoon (2 g) of garlic salt. Stir the turnips well to ensure that they’re evenly seasoned. If you like, you can add other spices or seasonings to the fries. Crushed red pepper adds a spicy kick.

steps.headline: Spread the fries out on  the pans and bake for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Once the fries are seasoned, use a potholder to carefully remove the baking sheet from the oven. Carefully spread the fries out on each in a single layer, and allow them to bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Because the pans will be very hot, take care when handling them so you don’t burn yourself.

steps.headline: Turn over the fries and bake them until browned.
steps.description: After 15 minutes, use a spatula to turn the turnip fries over and rotate the pans. Let the them bake for another 8 minutes, or until they are a golden brown.

steps.headline: Serve the fries while still warm.
steps.description: When the fries are finished baking, remove the pans from the oven. Transfer the turnips to a platter and serve while they are still hot. You can serve the fries with your favorite dipping sauce, but a parmesan aioli is an ideal option.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and grease a baking sheet.
steps.description: To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries, set the temperature to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully heat. Next, lightly grease a baking sheet with olive oil to prevent the fries from sticking. You can substitute canola oil for the olive if you prefer.

steps.headline: Mix the Parmesan cheese, Italian seasoning, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Add ¼ cup (20 g) of grated Parmesan cheese, 2 teaspoons (5 g) of Italian seasoning blend, and salt and black pepper to taste to a small bowl. Use a fork to mix the ingredients together so they’re well-blended. If you like, you substitute or mix other herbs in with the seasonings, such as dried thyme or dried marjoram.

steps.headline: Toss the turnip wedges with the olive oil.
steps.description: Place 2 large turnips that have been peeled and cut into wedges into a large bowl. Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of olive oil, and toss well so the turnip fries are well coated. You can substitute canola oil for the olive oil if you prefer, though the flavor won’t be as rich.

steps.headline: Add half of the seasoning mixture to the turnips and toss together.
steps.description: Once the turnip fries are coated with the oil, sprinkle half of the seasoning mixture over them. Stir the seasonings in so the turnips are fully coated.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the remaining cheese mixture over the turnips and toss again.
steps.description: After you’ve mixed the first half of the seasonings into the turnips, add the remaining seasoning mixture to the fries. Toss them again to evenly distribute the seasonings. If your fries don’t appear to have enough seasoning, you can mix up another batch of the Parmesan cheese and seasoning mixture and add as much as necessary to flavor the fries.

steps.headline: Bake the fries until they are golden brown.
steps.description: When the fries are properly seasoned, spread them out on the greased baking sheet in a single layer. Place them in the preheated oven, and allow them to bake until they are golden brown, which should take approximately 30 minutes. Halfway through the baking process, turn the fries over to ensure that they cook evenly.

steps.headline: Place the fries on a platter and serve.
steps.description: When the fries are finished baking, remove the baking sheets from the oven. Transfer the fries to a platter and serve while they are still warm. The herbed turnip fries pair well with a garlic aioli or other creamy dipping sauce.

text: Frying Up Classic Turnip Fries Combine cornmeal, flour, salt, and pepper. Add 1 cup (150 g) of fine plain white cornmeal, 1 cup (125 g) of all-purpose flour, 2 teaspoons (12 g) of kosher salt, and ½ teaspoon (1 g) of black pepper to a large bowl. Whisk the ingredients together so they’re well blended. If you like, you can add other seasonings to the coating for the turnip fries. Garlic powder, cayenne pepper, and paprika are some options to consider. Toss the turnips in the buttermilk. Pour 2 cups (473 ml) of whole buttermilk into a large bowl. Add ¾ pound (340 g) of peeled turnips that have been cut into ⅓-inch (8-mm) thick sticks to the milk and toss well so they’re completely coated. If you don’t have buttermilk, use 2 cups (473 ml) of regular milk with 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of lemon juice mixed into it. Coat the turnips with the cornmeal mixture. After you’ve coated the turnip sticks in the buttermilk, place them in the cornmeal mixture. Toss them in the cornmeal until the turnip fries are completely coated, and place them on a plate or baking sheet lined with foil or parchment paper. Pour the oil into a skillet and heat. Fill a large skillet with ¼-inch (6-mm) of canola oil, and place it on the stove over medium heat. Allow the oil to heat for 5 to 7 minutes. You can substitute peanut or vegetable oil for the canola if you prefer. Fry the turnips in batches until golden brown. Once the oil is heated, add the turnip fries to the skillet in batches. Cook them until they are golden brown, which should take approximately 5 minutes. Turn the fries occasionally with a spatula as they’re frying to ensure that they cook evenly. Drain the fries and top with chives before serving. Use a slotted spoon to lift the turnip fries out of the oil and place them on a plate lined with paper towel. Allow the fries to drain for 2 to 3 minutes on the paper towel before transferring them to a platter. Sprinkle 2 tablespoons (6 g) of fresh, chopped chives over them and serve. You can serve the turnip fries with ketchup or your favorite dipping sauce. Preparing Baked Turnip Fries Preheat the oven and line a baking sheet. To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries, set the temperature to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (220 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully heat. Next, line a large baking sheet with parchment paper. You can substitute foil for the parchment paper if you prefer. Toss the turnips with the oil and spices. Place 1 pound (454 g) of turnips that have been peeled and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) thick sticks into a large bowl. Add 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil, ½ teaspoon (3 g) of salt, ¼ teaspoon (½ g) of black pepper, ¼ teaspoon (2 g) of paprika, ¼ teaspoon (¼ g) of garlic powder, and ¼ teaspoon (¼ g) of dried parsley, and mix well so the turnips are completely coated. You can substitute coconut oil for the olive if you prefer. Place the turnip fries on the baking sheet. When the turnip fries are seasoned, transfer them to the lined baking sheet. Spread them out in a single layer so they will cook evenly. Bake the turnip fries for half an hour. Place the baking sheet in the preheated oven. Allow the turnip fries to bake for 30 minutes. At the 15 minute mark, turn the fries over with a spatula so they cook evenly on both sides. Increase the oven temperature and cook for another 5 minutes. After the turnip fries have cooked for half an hour, increase the oven’s temperature to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius). Let the fries cook for another 5 minutes or until they are crispy. Keep a close eye on the fries for the last 5 minutes to ensure that they don’t burn. Serve the fries while they are still hot. When the turnip fries are finished baking, remove the baking sheet from the oven. Transfer the fries to a platter, and serve them while they are still warm. You can serve the baked turnip fries with ketchup, garlic aioli, or your favorite fry dipping sauce. Whipping Up Garlicky Turnip Fries Preheat the oven and pans. Set two baking sheets inside the oven. Turn the oven on and set the temperature to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (230 degrees Celsius). Allow both the pans and the oven to fully preheat. To make cleanup easier, you may want to line the baking sheets with foil or parchment paper. Toss the turnip sticks with olive oil. Place 4 turnips that have been peeled and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) sticks in a large bowl. Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of olive oil, and toss well so that the turnip fries are well coated. While olive oil provides the best flavor, you can substitute canola or vegetable oil if you prefer. Add the parmesan cheese and garlic salt to the fries. When the fries are coated with the oil, mix in 2 tablespoons (10 g) of grated Parmesan cheese and ¼ teaspoon (2 g) of garlic salt. Stir the turnips well to ensure that they’re evenly seasoned. If you like, you can add other spices or seasonings to the fries. Crushed red pepper adds a spicy kick. Spread the fries out on  the pans and bake for 15 minutes. Once the fries are seasoned, use a potholder to carefully remove the baking sheet from the oven. Carefully spread the fries out on each in a single layer, and allow them to bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Because the pans will be very hot, take care when handling them so you don’t burn yourself. Turn over the fries and bake them until browned. After 15 minutes, use a spatula to turn the turnip fries over and rotate the pans. Let the them bake for another 8 minutes, or until they are a golden brown. Serve the fries while still warm. When the fries are finished baking, remove the pans from the oven. Transfer the turnips to a platter and serve while they are still hot. You can serve the fries with your favorite dipping sauce, but a parmesan aioli is an ideal option. Preparing Herbed Turnip Fries Preheat the oven and grease a baking sheet. To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries, set the temperature to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully heat. Next, lightly grease a baking sheet with olive oil to prevent the fries from sticking. You can substitute canola oil for the olive if you prefer. Mix the Parmesan cheese, Italian seasoning, salt, and pepper. Add ¼ cup (20 g) of grated Parmesan cheese, 2 teaspoons (5 g) of Italian seasoning blend, and salt and black pepper to taste to a small bowl. Use a fork to mix the ingredients together so they’re well-blended. If you like, you substitute or mix other herbs in with the seasonings, such as dried thyme or dried marjoram. Toss the turnip wedges with the olive oil. Place 2 large turnips that have been peeled and cut into wedges into a large bowl. Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of olive oil, and toss well so the turnip fries are well coated. You can substitute canola oil for the olive oil if you prefer, though the flavor won’t be as rich. Add half of the seasoning mixture to the turnips and toss together. Once the turnip fries are coated with the oil, sprinkle half of the seasoning mixture over them. Stir the seasonings in so the turnips are fully coated. Sprinkle the remaining cheese mixture over the turnips and toss again. After you’ve mixed the first half of the seasonings into the turnips, add the remaining seasoning mixture to the fries. Toss them again to evenly distribute the seasonings. If your fries don’t appear to have enough seasoning, you can mix up another batch of the Parmesan cheese and seasoning mixture and add as much as necessary to flavor the fries. Bake the fries until they are golden brown. When the fries are properly seasoned, spread them out on the greased baking sheet in a single layer. Place them in the preheated oven, and allow them to bake until they are golden brown, which should take approximately 30 minutes. Halfway through the baking process, turn the fries over to ensure that they cook evenly. Place the fries on a platter and serve. When the fries are finished baking, remove the baking sheets from the oven. Transfer the fries to a platter and serve while they are still warm. The herbed turnip fries pair well with a garlic aioli or other creamy dipping sauce.
